title: Will the federal emergency increase in unemployment compensation benefits be extended before 1 August 2020?
possible_answers: Yes, at $600 or more per week
Yes, at less than $600 per week
preds: All chips on no. Not gonna happen today.
High opposition from the Republicans in the Senate. Republicants will try to leverage their vote  in the Senate, unlikely comprimise from Democrats

I can't keep track of the Senate's schedule... seriously, these are the worst employees I've ever had. I guess they thought now would be a good time to go on a long weekend.
https://www.cnn.com/2020/07/31/politics/stimulus-negotiations-state-of-play/index.html
Parties still apart and Dems willing to let deadline pass.  Last minute deal still in play. If deadline passes eventual deal to provide retroactive payments.
Depends on: is their Pressereferent on President Trump?

We are at the 11th hour now, lowering bin to zero, if Republicans wanted to reduce $600, they should have strategize sooner. It is too late to negotiate lower $600 to let's say $200 or 70%. Still leaving room that there might be an extension, though it seems very small now.
Senate leaves for the weekend while deadlocked, leaving millions in limbo.
Nevermind my previous update. "No dice" wins. https://mobile.twitter.com/JStein_WaPo/status/1288991622034857985
I was at 100% no then saw this tweet claiming Trump is urging an extension, meeting with Pelosi, Schumer, Mnuchen, Meadows tonight. https://mobile.twitter.com/kaylatausche/status/1288957303107059712
Talks have all but ceased, discord within the Republican party, there is no chance they get an emergency bill punched through tomorrow.

Not much time left -- so high "theta". However, big incentive to do some deal. Fairly unlikely to maintain at current level, but fairly likely to maintain at a lower level. As likely as not that no deal is done, however.
Nothing's changed except the deadline got closer...

I am putting a little more hope than most into the GOP agreeing on something today, although chances are they will not before tomorrow, possibly even next week (and it is certain some democrats will push back). Particularly due to Romney’s 2 choice proposal for states expected to be introduced today (people like options), and that Johnson’s proposal is gaining steam.  (Politico article today).
https://apple.news/ABCBU6eJXQKix1ewykQdLXQ

There were just too many moving parts for me to dial into this with any semblance of certainty (let alone confidence.)
That said, I just got an email from the state telling me my benefits are ending and why... So, they seem pretty confident and I'll go with that.  I'm sure there will be some sort of replacement, but not before the deadline.

I am owning the fact that I misread this question. I 100% guarantee this will be extended, likely at a lower rate ($400/week). And I did believe it would be done before it was set to expire (July 31) but not anywhere near the 94% I was forecasting. I became focused on it getting done and not the August 1 deadline for the question.
Now this is what realism dictates.

There is a possibility of a standalone vote on extending the expanded benefits because the House and Senate are so far away on the bill https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/509703-mcconnell-opens-door-to-smaller-coronavirus-relief-deal

Shifting more toward no and swapping more toward the continued at $600 option as I think an extension is still possible and Republicans would take heavy blame when people's unemployment benefits drastically reduce.
No progress toward extension today. Mark Meadows, WH Chief of Staff, said today "We're nowhere close to a deal. . . It means enhanced unemployment insurance provisions will expire.”

This is what my rationality commands.
As there's little to no rationality in this process, I'll probably be wrong.

It seems like everyone is too far apart to do anything more than either have nothing for a deal on Aug 1st, or have an extension [1]. https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/trump-push-short-term-coronavirus-aid-fix-draws-frosty-gop-n1235230

Changing gears - pressure is on Rs to come to alignment among themselves (which will be hard within this timeline) @juancambeiro's article shows the impasse they are facing Timing issue rather than outcome issue  (Note - Democrats might still cave for short term deal, but that'd be playing a good hand poorly)

"Negotiations on a new coronavirus relief bill hit an impasse on Capitol Hill on Wednesday ... A meeting between top White House officials and Democratic leaders ended with no agreement on extending emergency unemployment benefits that expire Friday or on reviving a moratorium on evictions that lapsed last week. That means some 20 million jobless Americans will lose $600 weekly enhanced unemployment benefits that Congress approved in March." https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2020/07/29/trump-pushes-short-term-fix-unemployment-insurance-eviction-moratorium/

Recent news indicates that a piecemeal approach to a relief package, perhaps including a short-term extension of unemployment benefits to provide additional time for negotiation, may be under consideration this week.  If so, it seems more likely that any interim compromise that might be reached this week would maintain the status quo ($600), as any reduction to the benefit would likely require additional negotiation.

Pelosi has the upper hand at this moment in time, but she is also beholdened to the monied interests. Let Trump suffer is what she ought to do. He needs that $600 more than most Americans because it's the economy (stupid). If Democrats agree to it as an urgent, separate, short term bill, she loses alot of leverage in the upcoming negotiations.  Her best move IMO is to let this news play out for a bit and then decide. Not happening in 3 days.

Chief of Staff Meadows declares White House and Congress "nowhere close to a deal" and additional federal payments "will expire on Friday." Ok. I don't always believe White House staffers are telling the truth to the press. But this I do believe. Source: https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/07/29/meadows-not-optimistic-covid-19-stimulus-deal/5539835002/
Republicans said that they were too far apart to have a deal by the 1st.  Probably the next week.

Given how far apart the House, Senate, and White House are, it seems next to impossible for anything to get passed now. No side seems to be treating the issue with urgency, preferring to hold on to their wish list rather than pass a smaller measure on this one issue.
It will only be extended at the rate the person can claim on unemployment. 50 weeks total.

We are 2 days away and so far no agreement.

A short term extension is possible though Pelosi is against a piecemeal approach. No way they are going to get anything else done Before Aug. 1. Republicans have passed nothing in the Senate and do not agree among themselves.

Strong public support to extend + Democratic leverage + Republican division = tossup. Anybody's guess.  Divided and Demoralized on Virus Aid, Republicans Ask, ‘What’s in the Bill?’ https://nyti.ms/2BD4U2L This sums it up:
"With so many Americans suffering — and an election so close at hand — it appears to be one of those “too big to fail” moments when not delivering federal relief just doesn’t seem like an acceptable outcome for those in power.  
Still, given the current state of things, failure remains a real possibility."

While conflict remains among Senate Republicans regarding extension, 62% of voters in swing states support extending the $600 benefit; only 36% oppose continuing the benefit.  This public support will add pressure to the Senate to approve some form of extension soon; however it remains unclear whether Republican leadership will resolve the internal divisions before Monday.  
https://www.cnbc.com/amp/2020/07/29/coronavirus-stimulus-voters-support-enhanced-unemployment-cnbcchange-poll-finds.html
Update based on date the the legislative process.
The split in ideas on how to move forward is too vast to bridge by the 1st. No movement on the ground for a vote this week.

way too much disarray. at this rate it will not pass next week let alone this week unless there are some massive downturns in the stock market.  https://www.politico.com/news/2020/07/28/republican-senators-gop-coronavirus-package-384522

Extending compensation benefits has broad support from both parties. Republicans want to keep the compensation benefits to increase the chances the president gets re-elected. Democrats want to keep their constituents happy.

Only the White House is currently talking about a vote this week, with House Speaker Pelosi rejecting their proposal outright over the weekend. The odds that both the House and the Senate are able to get a vote in by Friday when it is still unclear what the GOP will officially propose are slim, and the odds that said legislation will pass both bodies is even slimmer. However, there is a small possibility of emergency negotiations leading to a short-term, less than ideal solution for both sides.

All-in.  Was overweighted to bin2 for much of this...this doesn't reflect my actual view of current probability, but leaving it here for remainder of forecast will bring overall weighted average of all forecasts closer to current view.

An emergency extension is feeling more likely. This is a gear grinder... "No" is just political suicide. No one can spin it to an advantage. The drop-off in funds will lead to a deluge of defaults and tank the economy. Trump will intervene. He can literally buy votes at this moment. I am trying to think this through with logic. 
"No" tanks the economy. "Less" will be brutal but possible IF the GOP rallies and the Dems are forced into a corner. "$600 or more" is the path of least resistance to extend as is... GOP can complain about it, Trump can issue an emergency order. Simple.
Other than that, this is a toss-up for us outsiders. Here's what bothers me is the timing. Friday could come and go and Trump could sign an executive order on Monday. Oh well.
Less hopeful by Aug. 1. Will update at end of day depending on where negotiations stand.

If all the factions really wanted to get this done, they'd have started on it sooner and it would be up on third reading for final passage today or tomorrow.  Far as I can tell, nobody's even drafted an actual bill yet, so clearly this is not the case: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-usa-congress/republicans-democrats-face-tough-talks-on-coronavirus-relief-as-deadline-looms-idUSKCN24T1AZ

Like an animal in a trap, I have a feeling the GOP will chew off its own leg to get free of this issue. I'd be surprised if they don't rally together in light of this existential crisis. (I mean, the existence of the party, not the unemployed or those afflicted with C19.)
The Republicans have unveiled a plan with 70% wage replacement in UI. I think this definitely raises the odds of a deal by the end of the week, though not by much.

"In the new GOP plan, Senate Republicans propose cutting weekly emergency unemployment benefits from $600 to $200 until states can bring a more complicated program online." https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2020/07/27/senate-stimulus-coronavirus/
My thinking is they can not get it done by August 1.  They might, however, agree to pass a short extension of the $600 but there would be considerable opposition to that.

Sounds like there is still a week's worth of quacking and flapping and posturing and lying on all sides.  They will probably move fairly quickly once the previous legislation actually expires, though.  "Fairly quickly" still means end of August.

I have the feeling that this is one of the questions where a great deal of resolution ambiguity could creep in.. In my opinion, an extension of unemployment compensation benefits as such is unlikely, there could be a NEW package at or below the previous amount, with a slightly different formula for eligibility and technical detail.

At the moment, it looks like there will be no possibility of greater than $600/week with the GOP plan that just got released. https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2020/07/27/senate-stimulus-coronavirus/?tidr=a_breakingnews&hpid=hp_no-name_hp-breaking-news%3Apage%2Fbreaking-news-bar Passing a bill by the end of the week still seems less likely than not because of the short time frame.

https://www.cnn.com/2020/07/26/politics/white-house-negotiators-coronavirus-legislation/index.html The consideration of scaling back efforts before Republicans even put an offer on the table underscores just how difficult the coming bipartisan negotiations are expected to be. One of the primary reasons administration officials are considering a less ambitious effort is due to the initial meeting between Meadows and Mnuchin and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer last week, according to multiple officials. "They came away from that significantly less optimistic that something can get done," said one administration official. A scaled-back proposal would focus primarily on deadline issues -- like the unemployment benefits that expire at the end of July, as well as education funding just weeks before schools are set to open. Should Republicans decide to pursue the idea, it may also be used to put pressure on Democrats in advance of the unemployment benefit deadline. Pelosi, however, has made clear a multi-phased approach is not on the table for Democrats. "This is a package," Pelosi told reporters last week. "We cannot piecemeal this."

McConnel is managing expectations that this might take a couple of weeks to negotiate. By my count there are probably 10 staunch Republicans as the bill stands. There are 47 Democrat Senators.  This would put everyone into three seperate buckets. I have spent a lot of time thinking about how to structure this problem in my head. It is late so there will be cursing. t Bucket 1 (Spend a shit-ton of money): 
They want to spend a shit ton of money. Probably to the tune of 2+ Trillion  dollars. Currently with 47 votes. Maybe 46 give or take Kristen Sinema. Given the opening, we should expect a large fight dealing with schools probably next week  Bucket 2 (RAND PAUL AND CO): There are probably around 10 votes in this bucket. They don't want to spend a drop of money.  Bucket 3 (The good ol Neo-Cons): 
They want to spend less money than the Democrats in the party. Probably around the tune of 1 Trillion dollars.  This counts for approximately 41 votes.  You need 60 to pass a bill. That means that the Republicans will need 19 of the people who are against spending any money to come over to their side. That could come from the either side of the Aisle, but let's move under the assumption that Democrats (not named Kristen Sinema) could move over to the Republican party.  If you include Kristen Sinema, that would amount to 42 votes. Since I am kind of lazy, and there are at least some of them who are grandstanding, let's say that good ol' Mitch can get their votes. But per each vote that will take a half of day of time in negation each. For 18 votes, that will mean 9 days. Which will actually be over the deadline of this question.  1. https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/07/24/unemployment-benefits-congress-coronavirus/

Public support for extension:  A new Hill-HarrisX poll finds bipartisan support for extending the UI benefits that were part of the CARES Act for at least one more month. 35 percent of all registered voters say it should be extended until the duration of the coronavirus pandemic no matter how much it would cost. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yKl8F3kZzkU  2. NBC 5 Responds: Extra $600 Federal Unemployment Benefits Expire This Week
-
Zoga and Parks (0202) July 22, stated that: Lawmakers Haven't Agreed on Next Steps as Unemployment Remains High By the end of this week, unemployed Texans will see a dramatic drop in benefits when a supplemental federal benefit of $600 a week expires. The federal CARES Act provided an additional $600 weekly unemployment benefit through July 31 unless Congress passes legislation to extend the benefits. Actual payments end July 25 for most states, including Texas, because the CARES Act requires the subsidy to end on or before July 31. States pay benefits on a weekly calendar and due to administrative rules, end those payments before the 31. “There are some questions about why not the 31. The reason is it’s a Friday and the Texas Workforce Commission, by law, can not pay partial week benefits. A full benefit week begins on a Sunday and ends on Saturday,” said Cisco Gamez with the Texas Workforce Commission.
-
Reference
-
Zoga, D. & Parks, E. (2020). NBC 5 Responds: Extra $600 Federal Unemployment Benefits Expire This Week. NBC. July 22, 2020. Retrieved from
https://www.nbcdfw.com/news/nbc-5-responds/nbc-5-responds-extra-600-in-federal-unemployment-benefits-expire-this-week/2411265/

11 days to go everyone! Here’s the update via POLITCO’s Playbook. Anna Palmer and Jake Sherman write that it’s ‘hard to believe’ talks will be wrapped up by the end of July as both sides come to grips with the enormity of the task before them. A difference of priorities exists not just between Republicans and Democrats but between GOP senators and the White House. Leading Republicans including John Cornyn (Texas), Chuck Grassley (South Carolina), and John Thune (South Dakota) have dismissed many of the President’s policy preferences for the new coronavirus aid package as little more than a joke. Part of the divide stems from the fact that senators on both sides are increasingly concerned with solving America’s testing problem before tackling the issue of additional relief. Sen. Lamar Alexander summarized their position: ”My view is, we should do whatever we need to do to make sure we have adequate tests. All roads to open school, opening, going back to work, child care go, lead through testing.”  This renewed focus comes as the U.S.’s largest laboratory warns it will be almost impossible to increase capacity to cope with demand for COVID tests going into the Autumn flu season. Back-to-work bonuses can’t replace the $600 boost in unemployment, economists say
 JUL 15 2020
Greg Iacurcia 
KEY POINTS Republicans have called for replacing enhanced unemployment benefits with a back-to-work bonus for people who find jobs. 
The extra $600 weekly unemployment supplement ends after July 31.

I’m going to begin by establishing a base rate of between 14 and 45 days from next Wednesday, July 22. That’s when negotiations over new COVID relief are expected to begin in the Senate with both White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows and Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin present. It will be the first time that lawmakers really confront the complexity and boring bits of how to approach the crisis. Discussions are said to be focused on protections for schools and changes to labour and unemployment laws. [1] The base rate of between 14 and 45 days is a rough estimate based on the experience of the two biggest crisis laws of recent times. The Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 or “bank bailout” took 14 days to become law from its initial proposal on September 19, 2008 to final signing by President Bush on October 3. [2][3] The Patriot Act was passed 45 days after 9/11. [4] There is little doubt of increasing pressure on politicians to act and despite posturing by the President and others I would suggest we are looking at the shorter end of 14 to 45 days. [5][6] But with just ten days  from the beginning of negotiations on July 22 and August 1, I think it is fair to say we will ‘Probably not’ see an extension of unemployment benefits before then and if we do it will most likely be smaller than the previous $600 a week with Senate Republicans reluctant to spend too heavily. [3]https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=95336601

Republicans would be absolute fools not to pass something this close to the election.    First, it will keep the recession from getting worse, and second, many those who are unemployed, many now in red and swing states, e.g., Oklahoma and Florida, are swing voters or pro-Trump.    The only questions are the amount and the dates of passage.  I suspect that something will pass before August 1, because the Republican's backs are against the wall.  After all, in almost every other developed country, the coronavirus has all but disappeared.   Democrats will have an easy time blaming them  for a very different and tragic result.    McConnell is very realistic in these situations, and he wants to keep as many Republican senate seats as possible. He will be willing to suffer a short term loss on this issue for the long term gain of increasing the odds of keeping the senate in Republican hands.  He will agree to whatever he needs to in order to reduce the negative economic effects of the coronavirus.   Thus, he needs to do two things:  reduce the daily financial strain of the unemployed, and get as many of unemployed as he can to return to work.    I think the most likely outcome is that the coronavirus unemployed will receive a weekly amount subject to cap that will likely be a percentage (perhaps 100%)  of  a workers previous weekly earnings or $600, whichever is less. It is highly likely any extension will pass before benefits run out for the reasons stated above.  If the second option was $600 or LESS per week, this question would be a no brainer.   I could see the Republicans insisting on a small "up to" cap of maybe $500 or $400 per week.  Yet, things are real bad, and the Republican's are rightly getting the blame.  I think they will see the higher limit of $600 as a necessary evil at this time. Trump only wants to win the election.  He has no ideology of any kind, except for doing what is good for him. I’ll start by breaking this into two parts:
1. Probability extra UI benefits get extended
2. If they are extended, probability that they are greater or equal to $600 For #1 I think time is of the essence. The CARES Act took 8 calendar days from introduction to signing (3/19-3/27). By that logic, no progress by mid-next week is going to increase the probability of “No”. Since the Senate won’t start debate until next week this is a tight timeline. That being said, the economic impact of not extending (especially as shutdowns return) is well-known. I can’t imagine a president who has tied his political future to the economy letting personal incomes fall by ~5%. Therefore, I think there is a ~70% chance that we’ll get something. The reason I’m not higher is the risk that something is agreed to after Aug 1 and applied retroactively.  In terms of the amount, I think this will be the source of compromise. An extension with a lower benefit would mean that both parties have something to tout and something to attack the other with. In politics that is a win-win.  Hard for me to be a bit more quantitative on this. Will see how events transpire
little or no chance of getting through senate by months end

The Republican objection to the supplemental unemployment benefit is that it causes unemployment to pay more than work and thus starves employers of the labor they need to keep their businesses running.  I see two possible scenarios: 1) Republicans propose less than $600 and the Democrats accept in return for something they want 2) Republicans propose less than $600 (or $0 and a "back-to-work bonus"), the Democrats won't compromise, and the benefit expires
